titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Stereoscopic cards and Viewer 1894-1913
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Mark O'English

publicationstmt.publisher: Washington State University Libraries Manuscripts, Archives, and Special Collections

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Suzanne James-Bacon. 2016

repository.corpname: Washington State University Libraries, Manuscripts, Archives and Special Collections

did.abstract: Stereoscopes (also known as stereographs, or stereoscopic views) are generally sets of two photographs mounted side-by-side on cards, designed so that when looked at through a viewer they would appear three dimensional. The collection consists of stereoscopic cards and one viewer. While the images are mostly tourist in nature and cover much of the world, the images published by the Kinsey Photograph Studio (of Sedro-Woolley, WA) are all of Washington state's North Cascades.

bioghist.p: Stereoscopes (also known as stereographs, or stereoscopic views) are generally sets of two photographs mounted side-by-side on cards, designed so that when looked at through a viewer they would appear three dimensional. They came into popularity in the late 1800s, and peaked in popularity between 1900 and 1940.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of stereoscopic cards and one viewer. While the images are mostly tourist in nature and cover much of the world, the images published by the Kinsey Photograph Studio (of Sedro-Woolley, WA) are all of Washington state's North Cascades.

arrangement.p: Items in the collection come from five publishers: International Stereographic Co.; Keystone View Company; Kinsey Photograph Studio; "Popular Series" [poss. by J Fortesuce Mann]; Underwood and Underwood. Most publishers have an item number on the image, and so the stereographs are organized alphabetically by publisher, and then by the publisher's number within those. Where no number is given, items are generally organized by date. Within the largest series (Keystone View Company), the publisher's number system is loosely geographical.

accessrestrict.p: This collection is open and available for research use.

userestrict.p: Items in this collection are likely no longer in copyright.

prefercite.p: Manuscripts, Archives, and Special Collections, Washington State University Libraries, Pullman, WA.

acqinfo.p: The majority of the Stereoscopic cards and Viewer in this collection were donated to MASC by Trevor James Bond on July 16, 2012

processinfo.p: This collection was processed by University Archivist Mark O'English in July, 2012.

controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the online catalog. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons, or places should search the catalog using these headings.

did.unittitle: "Popular Series" [poss. by J Fortesuce Mann]. 5 items. Undated.
Underwood and Underwood. 15 items. 1889-1904. Includes "Heroic Washington Volunteers advancing -Filipinos 800 yards in front- Taguig, Philippines, 1899"
Hand-held stereoscopic viewer. Keystone View Company, Meadville, PA.
